questions.question_text: A cloud engineer notices on a dashboard that the host is close to reaching maximum capacity for the CPU and memory in the cloud environment, which could cause performance issues. The cloud environment has 100 servers, with 25% of the servers consuming their compute only during peak business hours, 25% consuming half of the allocated resources, and the remaining 50% using the compute during off hours. Which of the following should the engineer perform to optimize the efficiency of the compute usage in the cloud?

discussion.content: You should be using automatic scaling
the answer is D, the whole point of cloud is to not have to worry about those kind of administrative tasks so autoscale your solutions!
not D. auto scaling is for guest not host

I don't see how adjusting the cloud workload would be efficient, you will run into issues in the future. 

Answer D. Automatic scaling will size according to load.

How I see it is if you migrate an application to a different host, you would be taking the same load off of one server and applying it to another. Thus you take one out and put one back in and have the same usage results. I would agree with answer D which would allow your servers to scale up during times of high usage, but scale down when usage decreases. This is more efficient than having hard configurations of memory and compute.
The only right answer is B
I think B is correct as 50% of the machines are not being used it's best capacity.

choices.A: Add additional CPUs and RAM to the host that is serving the cloud.
choices.B: Adjust the cloud workload by migrating resource-intensive applications to different hosts.
choices.C: Add additional hosts to the environment using the cloud management tool.
choices.D: Enable automatic scaling in the cloud management tool.

discussion.content: Answer is A, there is not need to change Cloud B as Cloud A has all the needed requirements
Changing the RPO is not a matter of just writing a new SLA. I think A will be the best approach, it recovers data faster and fewer changes to the infrastructure.
it is asking for "BEST" approach. A is best, but will cost the customer more money, but that is not our concern here. No need to change any settings.
D is correct. In Cloud A, RPO (5 minutes) does not meet customer needs(RPO 15 minutes).

comments.content:
It's "no more than 15". 5 is no more than 15 so it's valid.
A is correct
Less RPO time is better than D.. SO Answer is A

discussion.content: Answer is D

questions.question_text: A cloud administrator is managing two private cloud environments. In cloud A, the disaster recovery solution has an SLA for RPO of five minutes and RTO of one hour. In cloud B, the disaster recovery solution has an SLA for RPO of one hour and RTO of 24 hours. A new customer's application requires that, in case of a disaster, no more than 15 minutes of data can be lost, and it should be fully recovered within one day. Which of the following would be the BEST approach to this application?

choices.D: Change the cloud B disaster recovery solution so RPO will be 15 minutes
choices.A: Tell the customer cloud A is the best solution
choices.B: Put it in cloud B and ask the customer to create snapshots every 15 minutes
choices.C: Both cloud A and cloud B would suit the customer's needs

discussion.content: C- if you sum host 1 & 2 and try to cover the load on 3-5 you are over capacity, NOT D disk will be covered
Agree with Billw => C
I also think it is CPU not Disk

questions.question_text: Email users report that it takes more than one minute to open emails, including those without attachments. There are three email instances in three different regions hosted by the same CSP. Other applications hosted by the same CSP have no reported issues. Which of the following solutions BEST resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Answer should not be A. For all available CSP in the industry, the minimum bandwidth for a VM is 1Gbps. This bandwidth is enough for end users to load non-attachment emails (tens of KB in size) in less than 1 minutes. Since there are 3 mail instances hosted in different regions, the total "logical bandwidth" for email services is at least 3Gbps.

B and C are irrelevant.

D should be the answer. Email service is IOPS intensive and lack of IOPS can dramatically cause performance degrade.
3 instances in 3 regions + slow, there must be something common, should be C. for those emails without attachment, it maybe in the real-time scanning queue.

If you assume the antivirus would be used to protect attachments, then you can rule that out as a factor since messages without attachments are still slow to load. I would go with D. Considering other instances are working fine and the email instances are in 3 regions, the chances of 3 regions suffering from bandwidth issues at the same time is slim.

i agree that the answer is C, because the problem is antivirus on each user device. Mails like Outlook is SaaS. There is no problem on CSP, because there is no report issue from other applications. A,B and D show the problem is on CSP.
It's either A or D
Right answer is D
I think it's A. B don're solve the problem which is the main point.

I disagree, I think the answer is B. 
> A is not correct because other applications from the CSP are performing just fine. 
> C is not correct because it happens on emails both with/without attachments.
> D is also incorrect because IOPS would an unlikely cause of slowness in this scenario nor do we have monitoring data to prove that theory. 

B is correct because the unknown needs to be monitored to determine what is peaking so we can form a theory/plan of action.
Agree A

The Answer is A
like Neil stated "even mail without attachments" so the Anti-Virus isnt slowing down anything

Even mails without attachments have problems, so not the Anti-virus's problem. 
"There are three email instances in three different regions hosted by the same CSP" > same CSP, which mains a bandwidth problem with that CSP.

choices.C: Check the antivirus software settings and disable real-time message scanning.
choices.B: Install monitoring software on the email instances.
choices.D: Ensure the requested IOPS are being provided to the email instances.
choices.A: Confirm that the email instances have sufficient bandwidth.
Orchestrate a job to rotate the logs and upload to external storage.
choices.D: Add additional storage space to the log directory for the servers.
choices.C: Archive the existing logs in the directory and upload to external storage.
choices.B: Delete any log files in the directory that are larger than 20MB.

discussion.content: Answer is A
A. Orchestrate a job to rotate the logs and upload to external storage.
For some reason several of the questions have the answer at the end of the last multiple choice option. In this instance, A.
